contained.summary:
Patient with symptoms and exam consistent with acute otitis media.
There are no signs of mastoiditis, serious bacterial infection, or sepsis at this time, and the patient is otherwise
well appearing and well hydrated. We have reviewed the watch and wait approach to antibiotic treatment and
patient/caregiver understood to start antibiotics if pain worsened in the next 48 hours despite analgesics and/or
if the child develops fever. Antibiotic prescription given to patient/caregiver, who has verbalized they understand
when to use it and rationale for not giving immediately. Reviewed diagnosis, expected course, and treatment
plan. Reviewed discharge instructions and return precautions, including seeking medical attention for new or worsening symptoms. Patient/Caregiver expressed understanding. All questions answered, and patient/caregiver
is comfortable with discharge plan.

payload.contentString:
You/your child has been diagnosed with a mild middle ear infection. We are going to use the "Watchful Waiting" approach to treatment, where we allow the infection to resolve on its own as long as the symptoms are mild.
The American Academy of Pediatrics recommends NOT treating ear infections with antibiotics if there are mild symptoms (mild pain and fever < 102F) for less than 3 days. The majority of ear infections are caused by viruses and will heal on their own without the bad side effects of antibiotics (stomach pains, diarrhea, allergic reactions, drug resistance).
If symptoms worsen/don't improve, or fever >102F, pick up your prescription for the antibiotic and start the medicine. You can also return to your pediatrician or here for reassessment.
It is important to treat your child's pain with ibuprofen (Motrin or Advil) every 6 hours or acetaminophen (Tylenol) every 4 hours as needed. Ibuprofen SHOULD NOT be given to children younger than 6 months of age.
If you have questions about how much medication to give your child, please ask your medical provider.

Warning signs that require immediate recheck by a medical provider:
* If your child takes a sudden turn for the worse
* Fever of 100.4F (38C) for > 4-5 days, or fever >106F
* Refusing to drink, no tears when crying; "sunken" eyes or dry mouth; reduced diapers/urinating
* Inconsolable, severe headache, confusion, or severe sleepiness
* Fast breathing, trouble breathing, or using extra chest muscles to breathe
* Persistent vomiting
* Neck pain and/or stiffness
* Cool hands/feet
* New rash

payload.contentString:
You/your child has a fever that is most likely caused by a virus based on their current symptoms. Fever is the body's way of fighting infection. It will not cause harm to you/your child.

Generally, higher fever will make you/your child look and feel sicker, but higher fever DOES NOT mean that you/your child has a more serious illness—as long as they are fully vaccinated, have no underlying chronic illness and are behaving normally, there should be no immediate cause for concern.

You can treat fever with ibuprofen (Motrin or Advil) every six hours for acetaminophen (Tylenol) and every four hours as needed. Ibuprofen SHOULD NOT be given to children younger than six months of age. The goal is NOT to make the temperature normal. As long as you reduce the fever just enough to make your child more active and comfortable, that is what we would like you to achieve.
If you have questions about how much medication to give your child, please ask your medical provider.

It is important to encourage liquid intake. The best time to try to hydrate is one hour after Motrin or Tylenol, when the fever is reduced and the child feels better.

Since your/your child's symptoms are likely caused by a virus, antibiotics are not needed at this time. Keep in mind that along the course of a viral illness, bacterial infections can develop (including ear infections, pneumonia, and sinusitis), so see your doctor or return for worsening/persistent symptoms or concerning new symptoms.

Warning signs that require immediate recheck by a medical provider:
* If your child takes a sudden turn for the worse
* Fever of 100.4F (38C) for > 4-5 days, or fever >106F
* Refusing to drink, no tears when crying; "sunken" eyes or dry mouth; reduced diapers/urinating
* Inconsolable, severe headache, confusion, or severe sleepiness
* Fast breathing, trouble breathing, or using extra chest muscles to breathe
* Persistent vomiting
* Neck pain and/or stiffness
* Cool hands/feet
* New rash

payload.contentString:
You/your child likely has an upper respiratory infection (also known as a "URI") that is usually caused by a virus. Symptoms can include fever, cough, and congestion.

Unfortunately, most over-the-counter cough and cold remedies do not work in children and can have dangerous side effects.

The American Academy of Pediatrics does not recommend cough/cold remedies in children less than six years old.
Some treatments that may improve cough include honey-based remedies, which is ONLY for children more than one year old, or Vicks VaporRub for children more than two years old. Make sure Vicks Vapor Rub is only applied to the skin and not near the mouth, as it can be dangerous if ingested. You may also use a cool mist humidifier, nasal saline spray/drops, and suctioning of nose (or blowing nose) for nasal congestion.

You can treat fever with Ibuprofen ( Motrin or Advil) every 6 hours or acetaminophen (Tylenol) every 4 hours as needed. Ibuprofen SHOULD NOT be given to children younger than 6 months of age. The goal is not to make the temperature normal. As long as you reduce the fever just enough to make your child more active and comfortable, that is what we would like to achieve.

If you have questions about how much medication to give your child, please ask your medical provider. It is important to encourage liquid intake. The best time to try to hydrate is one hour after Motrin or Tylenol, when the fever is reduced and the child feels better. Since your/your child's symptoms are likely caused by a virus, antibiotics are not needed at this time. Keep in mind that along the course of a viral illness, bacterial infections can develop (including ear infections, pneumonia, and sinusitis). So see your doctor or return for worsening/persistent symptoms or concerning new symptoms.

Warning signs that require immediate recheck by a medical provider:
-If your child takes a sudden turn for the worse,
-Fever of 100.4 F), (38 C), for >4 to 5 days, or fever >106 degreesF
-Refusing to drink, no tears when crying; 'sunken" eyes or dry mouth; reduced diapers/urinating.
-Inconsolable, severe headache, confusion, or severe sleepiness.
-Fast breathing, trouble breathing, or using extra chest muscles to breathe.
-Persistent vomiting.
-Neck pain and/or Bye.
-Cool hands/feet.
-New rash.

payload.contentString:
Conjunctivitis is an infection of the outside lining of the eye. Viruses or bacteria can cause conjunctivitis. It is very contagious. 

The child is contagious until he/she has no more eye discharge. Hand washing may help prevent spread of the illness to others.
-Call your doctor if not better in 2 to 3 days. 
-Use any medications as directed. 
-Soak off crusts with moist cotton balls, then throw away. Do not reuse. 
-Avoid rubbing the eye

Warning signs that require IMMEDIATE recheck by a medical provider:
Trouble seeing.
Redness or swelling around the eye/eyelids
Pain in the eye, light hurts the eye, or trouble moving eye. 
Eye appears to be bulging.
Ear pain develops.
Fever develops or no better in 1-2 days.
Sicker, fussier, less active.

contained.summary:
Patient with pharyngitis, likely of viral etiology. Patient is non-toxic, clinically hydrated, has no respiratory distress, and is well perfused. No signs of serious bacterial infection, peritonsillar abscess, or sepsis at this time to indicate need for oral antibiotics, further imaging or additional testing. Rapid strep test negative, throat culture or NAAT test is pending at this time. Will contact patient if culture/NAAT is positive and begin antibiotics at that time.

Reviewed symptomatic treatment at home with pain control with acetaminophen or ibuprofen and encouraging fluid intake. 

Reviewed diagnosis, expected course, and reasons to seek urgent and/or emergent care. Discharge instructions reviewed; patient expressed understanding, all questions were answered, and patient is comfortable with discharge plans.

payload.contentString:
You have a throat infection referred to as "pharyngitis." At this time, you appear to have a viral throat infection based on your negative rapid strep test.

A second test for strep (a "throat culture") has been sent, and we will call you in 2-3 days if it is positive for strep. Of note, we do not routinely call if the throat culture is normal. A viral throat infection should get better in several days without antibiotics.

It is important to encourage liquid intake, ideally with Pedialyte or Gatorade as they contain sugar and salt which are important for the body. Since your symptoms are likely caused by a virus, antibiotics are not needed at this time. Keep in mind that along the course of a viral illness, bacterial infections can develop (including ear infections,
pneumonia, and sinusitis) so see your doctor or return for worsening/persistent symptoms or concerning new symptoms.

Warning signs that require IMMEDIATE recheck by a medical provider:
* If you take a sudden turn for the worse
* Fever of 100.4F (38C) for > 4-5 days, or fever >106F
* Unable to swallow, unable to open mouth fully
* Dizziness, neck pain/swelling
* Unable to drink, "sunken" eyes or dry mouth
* Persistent vomiting, bloody stools, severe/worsening abdominal pain/right lower abdominal pain,
* Severe headache, confusion, or severe sleepiness
* Fast breathing, trouble breathing, or using extra chest muscles to breathe
* Neck pain and/or stiffness
* Cool hands/feet
* New rash

payload.contentString:
You/your child most likely has a stomach virus based on their current symptoms. Stomach viruses can cause vomiting and/or diarrhea.

The best treatment for this is to make sure your child is drinking appropriate amounts of liquids. Pedialyte or Gatorade is preferred as they contain sugar and salt. Ice pops/popsicles are also an excellent option for rehydrating. The best way to give fluids is in small amounts frequently (not more than 1 ounce every 10 minutes). Try to avoid milk or very sugary juices for several days as they can worsen diarrhea. As long as your child is drinking fluids well, you don't need to worry if they are not eating solid foods over the next couple of days. If it seems like they are getting better, you can then slowly introduce basic foods (BRAT diet - bananas, rice, apples, toast).
You can use acetaminophen (Tylenol) or ibuprofen (Motrin or Advil) as needed for pain/fever. Children under the age of 6 months should not be given ibuprofen. Please ask your provider if you have questions about the right dose for your child. The best time to try to hydrate is 1 hour after Tylenol/Motrin, when the fever is low and the child feels better.
Your child's symptoms are probably caused by a virus, so antibiotics are not needed at this time. Keep in mind that along the course of a viral illness, bacterial infections can develop so see your doctor or return for worsening/persistent symptoms or concerning new symptoms.

Warning signs that require immediate recheck by a medical provider:
* If your child takes a sudden turn for the worse
* Fever of 100.4F (38C) for > 4-5 days, or fever >106F
* Refusing to drink, no tears when crying; sunken eyes or dry mouth; reduced diapers/urinating
* Persistent vomiting, bloody stools, severe/worsening abdominal pain/right lower abdominal pain,
* Inconsolable, severe headache, confusion, or severe sleepiness
* Fast breathing, trouble breathing, or using extra chest muscles to breathe
* Neck pain and/or stiffness

Your child has been diagnosed with abdominal "belly" pain.
There are many causes of abdominal pain, including viruses, constipation and cramping. Your child may need more tests or may need to be seen for again to figure out the cause of the pain if it continues.
At this time, your child's pain does not seem to be caused by anything dangerous. However, sometimes more serious problems like appendicitis, abscesses, etc. can start out mild but can become worse over time.

 It is VERY IMPORTANT that you have your child rechecked by your doctor, return or go to the nearest Emergency Department for a recheck if he/she is not better in the next few days.

You can trial a pain reliever like acetaminophen (Tylenol) or a laxative like polyethylene glycol (Miralax) to see if there is improvement.

Drink lots of fluids.

Warning signs that require immediate recheck by a medical provider:
*Increasing pain or pain that does not go away.
*Vomiting many times or if your child cant keep any liquids down.
*Dark green or bloody vomit, or blood in the stool causing it to be red or black and tarry.
*Yellowing of the skin or eyes, or dark brown, tea-colored urine.
*Signs of dehydration, which include no urine for 6-8 hours, dry mouth, lethargy, and/or no tears.

payload.contentString:
Your child is likely constipated - retention of hard stool that can cause pain, difficulty stooling, and occasionally urinary retention and vomiting. At this time your child has a normal abdominal exam. We do not see any signs of any surgical or infectious problem at this time.

How do I take care of this at home?
The best treatment for constipation is changing diet - increasing fiber with fruits and vegetables. It is also helpful to drink more water throughout the day. You may have been prescribed polyethylene Glycol (Miralax) to help loosen the stool (it is also available over the counter without a prescription). Take 1/2 to 1 cap per day dissolved in 8 oz of any liquid (milk, juice, water). Continue the miralax for 2 weeks or until the stool has consistency of applesauce, then can decrease the miralax a little bit each day until you no longer need it. You can also use Fiber Gummies (over the counter) to keep the stools soft.

Your child should be seen by your doctor in 2 days for reassessment if the pain continues.

Warning signs that require immediate recheck by a medical provider:
* Pain that persists, worsens, or moves to the right lower region of the abdomen, or your child has persistent vomiting

payload.contentString:
Influenza ("the flu") is a viral illness that causes multiple symptoms, including significant fatigue, fevers, muscle aching, headache, and a dry, hacking cough. It differs from the common cold in that it can cause more fatigue/body aches and can last a bit longer (sometimes up to 1 week).

ANTIVIRAL MEDICATION: It is important to remember that most patients will recover fully without antiviral medications. Occasionally your medical provider will prescribe an antiviral medicine (Tamiflu/oseltamivir or Xofluza/baloxavir), which can decrease the duration of illness by about one day if started within the first two days of symptom onset. Also remember that Tamiflu/oseltamivir can cause occasional vomiting.

FLUIDS: It is important to encourage liquid intake (Pedialyte or Gatorade works best). The best time to hydrate is about an hour after you/your child take fever-reducing medications (e.g., ibuprofen or acetaminophen), when your energy is higher.

NASAL CONGESTION: Suction the nose of infants with a rubber bulb syringe or over-the-counter suction devices, like NoseFrida after putting in a couple of drops of nasal saline in each nostril. Older children/young adults may use saline nasal spray to keep their nasal passages moist.

FEVER: You can treat fever with ibuprofen (Motrin or Advil) every 6 hours or acetaminophen (Tylenol) every 4 hours as needed. Ibuprofen SHOULD NOT be given to children younger than 6 months of age. The goal is NOT to make the temperature normal. As long as you reduce the fever just enough to make your child more active and comfortable, that is what we would like to achieve. If you have questions about how much medication to
give your child, please ask your medical provider.

COUGH: Over-the-counter cough and cold medicines have not been proven to help cough/congestion and are not recommended in children < 6 years old. Two non-medical treatments that have been shown to help cough are honey or honey-based cough syrups (e.g., Zarbee's or Hyland's) and Vicks VapoRub. Make sure Vicks VapoRub is only applied to the skin and not near the mouth, as it can be dangerous if ingested. Honey should
NEVER be used in a child under the age of one year.

ACTIVITY/SCHOOL/WORK: You/your child may return to daycare/school/work when the fever is gone for at least 24 hours and you/your child are feeling better.
Follow Up:
- Return or see your doctor for worsening symptoms or persistent symptoms greater than 3-5 days.

Warning signs that require IMMEDIATE recheck by a medical provider:
* If your child takes a sudden turn for the worse
* Fever of 100.4F (38C) for > 4-5 days, or fever >106F
* Refusing to drink, no tears when crying; "sunken" eyes or dry mouth; reduced diapers/urinating
* Persistent vomiting, bloody stools, severe/worsening abdominal pain/right lower abdominal pain,
* Inconsolable, severe headache, confusion, or severe sleepiness
* Fast breathing, trouble breathing, or using extra chest muscles to breathe
* Neck pain and/or stiffness
* Cool hands/feet
* New rash

payload.contentString:
Croup is a common condition caused by a virus, causing barky cough and sometimes a high-pitched whistling sound with breathing called stridor.

We gave your child a steroid (usually Dexamethasone) which should protect your child from difficulty breathing for 3 days - usually by that time the illness should be improved. The symptoms may continue but should be less severe as a result of the medication. You can give ibuprofen (Motrin or Advil) or acetaminophen (Tylenol) as needed for fever/pain.

Symptoms often get worse at night - if you notice loud breathing or difficulty breathing, you can try steam (run the shower in a closed bathroom), cool mist humidifier, or cool outside air.
Follow up with the pediatrician in 1 day if not improved or sooner as needed.

We also gave your child a steroid (usually Dexamethasone) which should protect your child from difficulty breathing for 3 days - usually by that time the illness should be improved. The symptoms may continue but should be less severe as a result of the medication. You can give ibuprofen (Motrin or Advil) or acetaminophen (Tylenol) as needed for fever/pain.

Symptoms often get worse at night - if you notice loud breathing or difficulty breathing, you can try steam (run the shower in a closed bathroom), cool mist humidifier, or cool outside air.
Follow up with the pediatrician in 1 day if not improved or sooner as needed.

* If your child takes a sudden turn for the worse
* Difficulty breathing despite treatment
* Worsening stridor (loud breathing) or stridor even while calm

payload.contentString:
Bronchiolitis is an infection caused by a virus that affects the lungs. This infection can cause a runny nose, fever, wheezing, coughing, and shortness of breath. Bronchiolitis is very unpredictable and even though child looks well now, your child's condition could abruptly change, even in a few hours. Bronchiolitis is caused by a virus, so antibiotics will not help.

Frequent nasal suction using normal saline. Suction prior to each feed and before bedtime.
Continue normal feeds. Monitor for urine output with wet diapers at least every 6-8 hours.
You can treat fever with ibuprofen (Motrin or Advil) every 6 hours or acetaminophen (Tylenol) every 4 hours as needed. Ibuprofen SHOULD NOT be given to children younger than 6 months of age. The goal is NOT to make the temperature normal. As long as you reduce the fever just enough to make your child more active and comfortable, that is what we would like to achieve. If you have questions about how much medication to give your child, please ask your medical provider.

If the doctor has prescribed any medication, use the medication only as prescribed.
Do not smoke around your child (in the house or car especially). Smoking will make your child's illness worse. If you do not smoke, avoid others that do, as smoke will make your child's symptoms worse.

Warning signs that require immediate recheck by a medical provider:
*Increased work of breathing (fast shallow breathing, nostril flaring, use of other muscles to breathe such as the abdominal muscles, and the muscles between the ribs).
* A respiratory (breathing) rate greater than 60 times a minute for an infant under 3 months old, greater than 50 times a minute for a baby 3-12 months old, and greater than 40 times a minute for a child over 12 months of age.
*Cyanosis (blue discoloration) around the lips or fingernails. If you see this call 911 immediately.
*Persistent wheezing that appears to cause the child some distress.
*Change in behavior (not interested in surroundings, difficulty waking from sleep, lethargy).
*Trouble feeding or talking.
*Signs of dehydration such as no urine for 8-10 hours, dry mouth or dry eyes.

Pneumonia is an infection of the lungs. Most cases are caused by infections from bacteria or viruses.Pneumonia may be mild or very severe. If it is caused by bacteria, you will be treated with antibiotics. It may take a few weeks to a few months to recover fully from pneumonia, depending on how sick you were and whether your overall health is good.
It is important to return to your doctor in 1-2 days for recheck to make sure that your child is improving.

How do I take care of this at home?
*Take the antibiotic as directed
*You can take ibuprofen or acetaminophen as needed for fever or any pain
*Drink plenty of fluids

payload.contentString:
You/your child has been treated for wheezing. Wheezing is caused by constriction/squeezing of the breathing tubes within the lungs, making it hard to breathe. This can often be treated with albuterol (from a pump or nebulizer machine) which helps to open the breathing tubes, making breathing easier. Some patients may also receive a single dose of a steroid (Dexamethasone) which decreases inflammation and swelling in the breathing tubes. This medicine can stay in the body for up to 3 days, so additional doses are usually unnecessary.

How do I take care of this at home?
*Avoid triggers of asthma/wheezing, including pet dander, smoke, cold air, pollen, dust, and/or chemical fumes
*Use albuterol nebulizer OR albuterol inhaler with spacer every 4-6 hours, as needed for
wheezing/cough/shortness of breath
*Use a cool mist humidifier
*Be sure to follow-up with you primary doctor as soon as possible (within the week) for re-evaluation of
patient's respiratory status

Warning signs that require IMMEDIATE recheck by a medical provider:
*If treatments are needed more frequently than every 4 hours
*Fast breathing, trouble breathing, or using extra muscles to breathe that is not improved with treatments
*Blue lips
*If your child takes a sudden turn for the worse

payload.contentString:
Urinary tract infection is an infection (illness caused by germs) of the parts of the body that make or hold urine. It can lead to burning and/or pain during urination (peeing). Sometimes fever can be the only sign of a urinary tract infection in infants and young children.
We sent a urine culture (a test to find out what type of germ is causing the infection) to the lab. We may call you in 48-72 hours with the results to talk about any changes in the treatment plan that need to be made based on these results.

How do I take care of this at home?
A UTI is a bacterial infection that is treated with antibiotics. Make sure to take the full antibiotic course, even if there is rapid improvement.
You can treat fever with ibuprofen (Motrin or Advil) every 6 hours or acetaminophen (Tylenol) every 4 hours as needed.Infants under the age of 6 months old should never receive ibuprofen. It you have questions about Tylenol or Motrin dosing please ask your provider. It is important to encourage liquid intake.
Soaking in a lukewarm tub a few times a day for 10 minutes can soothe the discomfort, but do not use bubble bath or strong soap. It is important that girls wipe from front to back after using the bathroom.

Warning signs that require immediate recheck by a medical provider:
* Increasing pain or burning with urination
* New fever or fever does not improve within 24 to 48 hours after starting antibiotics
* Back or abdominal/belly pain, vomiting
* No urine for more than 12 hours
* Refusing to drink, no tears when crying; "sunken" eyes or dry mouth; reduced diapers/urinating
* Inconsolable, severe headache, confusion, or severe sleepiness
* Fast breathing, trouble breathing, or using extra chest muscles to breathe
* Neck pain and/or stiffness
* Cool hands/feet
* New rash

You/Your child has been diagnosed with vaginitis, typically caused by irritation of the skin in the vaginal region. Common symptoms include pain with urination, mild discharge from the vagina, and redness of the skin. If a urinalysis was done, typically the results are negative which means there are no signs of a UTI. Sometimes a second test for UTI called a urine culture is sent to the lab; if sent we will only call with results in 2-3 days if the culture is positive for a UTI.

How do I take care of this at home?
*Warm water soaks in bathtub 2-3 times per day NO soap, shampoo or bubble bath in water
*Ibuprofen (Motrin or Advil) or acetaminophen (Tylenol) for discomfort as needed. Ibuprofen should not be
given to children under 6 months of age. Please ask your provider if you have any questions about dosing.
*After child urinates, clean area with warm water in squirt bottle and pat dry
*If your child is still in diapers, use a wet washcloth to clean genital area and pat dry
*Apply vaseline petroleum jelly or diaper cream to genital area/diaper area after urination

Warning signs that require immediate recheck by a medical provider:
* Unable to urinate
* Painful urination despite treatment listed above
* New onset fever, or persistent fever > 100.4F (38C) for > 3-4 days
* Severe abdominal pain or vomiting

How do I take care of this at home?

Your child has a cut to the face that required sutures (stitches). We do not
see any signs of a concerning brain injury at this time.

How do I take care of this at home?
Keep area dry for 24 hours, and then gently rinse 1-2 times daily with warm soap and water every day until the stitches are removed. Pat the wound dry; do not rub. If surgical glue or steri-strips were used, do NOT wash or rub the wound. Apply Bacitracin 2-3 times daily until stitches are removed. You can keep the wound covered when your child is awake and active.

Return here or your pediatrician for removal of sutures in 5-7 days.

Any time the skin is broken, a scar is likely to happen. Sutures help lessen the appearance of scarring when an injury occurs. There are some things you can do to help prevent scarring once the wound is completely healed.
Apply a moisturizer with SPF daily and apply extra sunscreen to that area more frequently when your child is in the sun. Do this for 6 months to a year. You can use silicone gel scar sheets or silicone scar gel. Apply and massage the scar nightly. You will not know the final appearance of a scar until 1 year after the injury, as all wounds "remodel" or change with time.

Warning signs that require IMMEDIATE recheck by a medical provider:
* Signs of infection: redness or red streaks spreading from the wound, drainage or discharge, swelling, fever,
increasing pain
* Wound opening
* Any sudden worsening of symptoms, such as severe headache
* Unusual behavior such as confusion, inconsolable crying or excessive sleepiness
* Vomiting
* Staggering/loss of balance, weakness of arms/legs, or seizure

payload.contentString:
Your child has a cut to the face that required closure of the skin. We do not see any signs of a concerning brain= injury at this time.

How do I take care of this at home?
The wound has been closed with Tissue Adhesive. This is equivalent to "superglue for skin."
*Keep wound completely dry for the first 24 hours after application.
*Do NOT immerse/submerge in water for 5 days
*Do NOT place any ointment on the Tissue Adhesive.
*Do NOT place adhesive tape directly over the Tissue Adhesive. -You may place a dressing or band-aid over the wound to prevent your child from picking at the Tissue Adhesive, avoiding contact of the adhesive tape with the
Tissue Adhesive.
*Do not pick, pull or scratch the Tissue Adhesive
*Tissue Adhesive wears off naturally after 5-7 days.
*Once healed be sure to use sunscreen to help reduce scarring.

Any time the skin is broken, a scar is likely to happen. Dermabond (tissue adhesive) helps lessen the appearance of scarring when an injury occurs. There are some things you can do to help prevent scarring once the wound is completely healed. Apply a moisturizer with SPF daily and apply extra sunscreen to that area more frequently when your child is in the sun. Do this for 6 months to a year. You can use silicone gel scar sheets or silicone scar gel. Apply and massage the scar nightly. You will not know the final appearance of a scar until 1
year after the injury, as all wounds "remodel" or change with time.

Warning signs that require IMMEDIATE recheck by a medical provider:
* Signs of infection: redness or red streaks spreading from the wound, drainage or discharge, swelling, fever,
increasing pain
* Wound opening
* Any sudden worsening of symptoms, such as severe headache
* Unusual behavior such as confusion, inconsolable crying or excessive sleepiness
* Vomiting
* Staggering/loss of balance, weakness of arms/legs, or seizure
* Neck pain, neck stiffness

payload.contentString:
Coxsackievirus is a viral illness that causes mouth ulcers and can cause blisters on the hands and feet. Since your child's symptoms are likely caused by a virus, antibiotics are not needed at this time. Fever can last 2-3 days, mouth ulcers resolve by 7 days, and rash on the hands and feet lasts up to 10 days. Your child can return to child care or school after the fever is gone (usually 2-3 days), as the rash is not contagious.

How do I take care of this at home?
*It is important to encourage liquid intake, ideally with Pedialyte or Gatorade as they contain sugar and salt which are important for the body.
*The best time to try to hydrate is 1 hour after Motrin or Tylenol, when the fever/pain is reduced and the child feels better.
*Please ask your provider if you have question about your child's Tylenol or Motrin dose.
*Cold drinks, milkshakes, popsicles, slushes, and sherbet are good choices.
*Avoid citrus, salty or spicy foods.
*The rash is usually not itchy, but itch can be treated with over the counter treatments like 1%
hydrocortisone/cortisone cream.
*Follow up with your PCP in 2-3 days if not improving.

Warning signs that require IMMEDIATE recheck by a medical provider
*If your child takes a sudden turn for the worse
*Fever of 100.4F (38C) for >4-5 days or fever over 106
*Dizziness, neck pain/swelling
*Refusing to drink, no tears when crying; "sunken" eyes or dry mouth; reduced diapers/urinating
*Persistent vomiting, bloody stools, severe/worsening abdominal pain/right lower abdominal pain
*Inconsolable, severe headache, confusion, or severe sleepiness
*Fast breathing, trouble breathing, or using extra chest muscles to breathe
*Neck pain and/or stiffness
*Cool hands/feet

payload.contentString:
The lesion(s) on your body is likely from an insect bite. The area of redness, when it develops this early, is usually from an allergic reaction.
There are no signs of infection at this time (usually infection occurs several days after the bite begins, and infection is usually very tender to touch).
It is important to return to clinic if the redness spreads, worse pain, fever, yellow discharge, generalized allergic reaction (difficulty breathing, body swelling) or an ulcer appears where the original insect bite occurred.

How do I take care of this at home?
* Apply 1% hydrocortisone to rash twice daily as needed for itching.
* Calamine lotion/oatmeal bath as needed.
* May ice insect bites as needed for itching.
*ANTIHISTAMINES - Cetirizine (Zyrtec, store brands, etc.) OTC:
6 months-2 years: 2.5 mg once a day
2-5 years : 5 mg once a day
6 years and older: 10mg once a day
*Please follow up with your doctor if this medication is not helping to improve your child's symptoms in 1 week.

Warning signs that require IMMEDIATE recheck by a medical provider:
* Spreading redness/rash
* Tenderness of the rash
* Fever greater than 100.4F
* Pain that is out of proportion with concern

payload.contentString:
Your X-ray performed today appears normal and we do not see any signs of a fracture/broken bone at this time.
Your child likely has a sprain or contusion (bruise).

How do I take care of this at home?
* If a splint was applied, please refer to our splinting handout for detailed splint care instructions.
* Sprains can be treated with the R.I.C.E approach. Rest is an important part of healing. Limit your child's activity until their pain is improved. Ice the injured body part for at least the first 48 hours. Compression with an ACE bandage can help to decrease swelling and provide support while your child's injury is healing. Be sure not to place the ACE wrap too tightly as this can decrease blood flow to that area. Elevation is also important to help decrease swelling.
* Apply a cold gel pack, bag of ice, or bag of frozen vegetables to the affected area every 1-2 hours for 15 minutes at a time for 48 hours from the time of the injury. Put a thin towel between the ice and your skin.
* Keep the extremity elevated above the level of the chest
* Give ibuprofen (Motrin or Advil) or acetaminophen (Tylenol) as needed for pain. Studies have shown that ibuprofen may be better at relieving fracture pain.
If symptoms do not improve within 1 week or worsen, follow up here or with a pediatric orthopedist as there can be injuries that are not detected on the initial X-ray.
We always have our X-rays double checked by a radiologist. If their X-ray interpretation is different, then we will call with within 24 hours.

Warning signs that require IMMEDIATE recheck by a medical provider:
* Signs of decreased blood flow the injured area - blue skin color, cold skin temperature, numbness severe/worsening pain, unable to walk.

contained.summary:
Patient with mild closed head injury. The neurologic examination is
normal. GCS is 15, there are no signs of basilar skull fracture, and mental status is at baseline. No additional
injuries were identified. Additionally, there is no history of vomiting, loss of consciousness, or irritability, and the
mechanism of injury was non-severe. Therefore, per PECARN, low risk of clinically significant traumatic brain
injury. Reviewed in detail return precautions, including irritability, seizures, excessive drowsiness or inability to
awaken, repeated vomiting, slurred speech, inability to recognize people or places, weakness or numbness in
arms or legs, unusual behavior changes, or loss of consciousness. If you/your child has any new onset or
persisting mild symptoms (nausea, mild headache, fatigue), it is important to follow-up with your doctor, as
sometimes concussions take time to develop. Discussed diagnosis and expected course. Follow up with PMD in 1-

no CAT scan or other test is needed.

How do I take care of this at home?

If your child has any persisting mild symptoms (nausea, mild headache, fatigue), it is important to follow-up with your doctor, as sometimes concussions take days to weeks after the injury to develop.
Recommend 1-2 days of physical/mental rest, during this time follow up with pediatrician, who can clear the child for gradual return to school and activities. Avoidance of activities that make symptoms worse is CRITICAL.
Early return to activities that DO NOT make symptoms worse leads to quicker recovery.

payload.contentString:
Diaper rash that lasts for more than a few days, even with changes to the diapering routine, might be caused by a yeast called Candida albicans. This rash is usually red, slightly raised, and has small red dots spreading beyond the main part of the rash. It often starts in the deep creases of skin and can spread to skin on the front and back of the baby. Antibiotics given to a baby or a breastfeeding mom can cause this, as they kill off the "good" bacteria that keep Candida from growing.

How do I take care of this at home?
* Use the prescribed cream.
* Check your baby's diaper often and change it as soon as it's wet or soiled.
* Gently clean the diaper area with soap and water and pat dry.
* Creams containing zinc oxide (like Desitin and Triple Paste) help to soothe skin and protect it from moisture. They should be smeared on thickly (like cake icing) at each diaper change.
* Let your baby go without diapers for several hours each day to give irritated skin a chance to dry and "breathe."

Warning signs that require recheck by a medical provider:
* If the rash doesn't go away, gets worse, or if sores appear on your baby's skin.
* Any fever greater than 100.4 F

* Check your baby's diaper often and change it as soon as it's wet or soiled.

* Creams containing zinc oxide (like Desitin and Triple Paste) help to soothe skin and protect it from moisture. They should be smeared on thickly (like cake icing) at each diaper change.
* Let your baby go without diapers for several hours each day to give irritated skin a chance to dry and "breathe."

payload.contentString:
Notes: Eczema is also called atopic dermatitis. It's a skin problem that causes intense itching and a raised rash. Sometimes the rash can be scaly. The rash isn't contagious. Your child can't catch it from others.

How do I take care of this at home?
* Use a moisturizer (examples include petroleum jelly, aquaphor, eucerin, cetaphil, lubriderm, aveeno) at least twice a day. It is also important to apply moisturizer after bathing - you can apply it while your child's skin is still damp after lightly drying with a towel.
* If you were prescribed a cream, use it as directed. If you were prescribed other medicine, give it exactly as directed.
* Have your child bathe in warm (not hot) water. Do not use bath oils.
* Don't use soap at every bath. When you do need soap, use a gentle, nondrying cleanser such as Aveeno, Basis, Dove, or Neutrogena.
* Can place cold, wet cloths on the rash to help with itching.
* Keep your child's fingernails trimmed and filed smooth to help prevent scratching. Wearing mittens or cotton socks on the hands may help keep your child from scratching the rash.
* Wash clothes and bedding in mild detergent.
* Use an unscented fabric softener.
* Choose soft clothing and bedding.
* Help your child avoid things that trigger the rash. These may include things like harsh soaps, itchy fabric, and stress.
* If itching affects your child's sleep, ask the doctor about giving your child an antihistamine that might reduce itching and make your child sleepy, such as diphenhydramine (Benadryl). Be safe with medicines. Read and follow all instructions on the label.

Warning signs that require IMMEDIATE recheck by a medical provider:
* Your child has a rash and a fever.
* Your child has new blisters, or a rash spreads and looks like a sunburn.
* Your child has crusting oozing sores.
* Your child has joint or body aches with a rash.
* Your child appears ill, has trouble breathing, or is very pale.
* Your child has signs of infection. These include: Increased pain, swelling, red, or warmth around the rash, red streaks leading from the rash, pus draining from the rash, a fever

payload.contentString:
The rash is consistent with poison ivy contact dermatitis. The rash typically appears 12-48 hours after exposure and may continue to appear for several days. The rash itself is not contagious, but the plant oils can spread from contaminated clothing, tools, or pets.

How do I take care of this at home?
*Any medications, such as oral or topical steroids, if prescribed
*ANTIHISTAMINES - Cetirizine (Zyrtec, store brands, etc.) OTC: 6 months-2 years: 2.5 mg once a day 2-5 years : 5 mg once a day 6 years and older: 10mg once a day. In certain situations, your provider may suggest doubling this dose to twice daily.
*Wash all clothing, shoes, tools, and pets that may have been exposed to remove plant oils
*Take cool baths with oatmeal or baking soda (1 cup per tub)
*Apply cool, wet compresses to affected areas for 15-20 minutes several times daily
*Use calamine lotion or zinc oxide for drying effect on blisters
*Keep fingernails short and avoid scratching to prevent secondary infection
*Please follow up with your doctor if these measures are not helping to improve your child's symptoms in 1 week.

Warning signs that require IMMEDIATE recheck by a medical provider:
*If your child takes a sudden turn for the worse
*Fever of 100.4F (38C) developing after rash appears
*Signs of secondary bacterial infection: pus, red streaking, increased warmth, swelling
*Difficulty breathing or swallowing
*Rash spreading to face, eyes, mouth, or genitals
*Severe swelling of affected areas
*Unable to swallow, unable to open mouth fully

payload.contentString:
Strep throat is a bacterial infection that causes sudden, severe sore throat and fever. Symptoms may include red, swollen tonsils that may have white or yellow patches. A strep test may be needed to tell if the sore throat is caused by strep bacteria. Treatment can help ease symptoms and may prevent future problems.

Follow-up care is a key part of your treatment and safety. Be sure to make and go to all appointments, and call your doctor if you are having problems. It's also a good idea to know your test results and keep a list of the medicines you take.


How can you care for yourself at home?

○ Take your antibiotics as directed. Do not stop taking them just because you feel better. You need to take the full course of antibiotics.

○ Strep throat can spread to others until 24 hours after you begin taking antibiotics. During this time, avoid contact with other people at work, school, or home, especially infants and children. Do not sneeze or cough on others, and wash your hands often. Keep your drinking glass and eating utensils separate from those of others. Wash these items well in hot, soapy water.

○ Gargle with warm salt water several times a day to help reduce swelling and relieve pain. Mix 1/2 teaspoon of salt in 1 cup of warm water.

○ Take an over-the-counter pain medication, such as acetaminophen (Tylenol), ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin), or naproxen (Aleve). Read and follow all instructions on the label.

○ Try an over-the-counter anesthetic throat spray or throat lozenges, which may help relieve throat pain.

○ Drink plenty of fluids. Fluids may help soothe an irritated throat. Hot fluids, such as tea or soup, may help your throat feel better.

○ Eat soft solids and drink plenty of liquids. Flavored ice pops, ice cream, scrambled eggs, sherbet, and gelatin dessert (such as Jell-O) may also soothe the throat.

○ Get lots of rest.

○ If you smoke, try to quit. If you can't quit, cut back as much as you can. Smoking can interfere with healing. If you need help quitting, talk to your doctor about stop-smoking programs and medicines. These can increase your chances of quitting for good. 

○ Use a vaporizer or humidifier to add moisture to the air where you sleep. Follow the directions for cleaning the machine. 


When should you call for help? 

Call your doctor now or seek immediate medical care if:

You have new or worse symptoms of infection, such as:
○ A new or higher fever.
○ A fever with a stiff neck or severe headache.
○ New or worse trouble swallowing.
○ Pain that becomes much worse on one side of your throat.

Watch closely for changes in your health, and be sure to contact your doctor if:

You are not getting better after 2 days (48 hours) after taking an antibiotic.

payload.contentString:
Headaches have many possible causes. Most headaches aren't a sign of a more serious problem, and they will get better on their own. Home treatment may help you feel better faster. The doctor has checked you carefully, but problems can develop later. If you notice any problems or new symptoms, get medical treatment right away.
Follow-up care is a key part of your treatment and safety. Be sure to make and go to all appointments, and call your doctor if you are having problems. It's also a good idea to know your test results and keep a list of the medicines you take.

How can you care for yourself at home?
Rest in a quiet, dark room until your headache is gone. Close your eyes and try to relax or go to sleep. Don't watch TV or read.
Put a cold, moist cloth or cold pack on the painful area for 10 to 20 minutes at a time. Put a thin cloth between the cold pack and your skin.
Use a warm, moist towel or a heating pad set on low to relax tight shoulder and neck muscles.
Have someone gently massage your neck and shoulders.
Take pain medicines exactly as directed.
○ If the doctor gave you a prescription medicine for pain, take it as prescribed.
○ If you are not taking a prescription pain medicine, ask your doctor if you can take an over-the-counter medicine.
Do not ignore new symptoms that occur with a headache, such as a fever, weakness or numbness, vision changes, or confusion. These may be signs of a more serious problem.

To prevent headaches

Keep a headache diary so you can figure out what triggers your headaches. Avoiding triggers may help you prevent headaches. Record when each headache began, how long it lasted, and what the pain was like (throbbing, aching, stabbing, or dull). Write down any other symptoms you had with the headache, such as nausea, flashing lights or dark spots, or sensitivity to bright light or loud noise. Note if the headache occurred near your period. List anything that might have triggered the headache, such as certain foods (chocolate, cheese, wine) or odors, smoke, bright light, stress, or lack of sleep.
Find healthy ways to deal with stress. Headaches are most common during or right after stressful times. Take time to relax before and after you do something that has caused a headache in the past.
Try to keep your muscles relaxed by keeping good posture. Check your jaw, face, neck, and shoulder muscles for tension, and try relaxing them. When sitting at a desk, change positions often, and stretch for 30 seconds each hour.
Get plenty of sleep and exercise.
Eat regularly. Long periods without food can trigger a headache.
Limit caffeine by not drinking too much coffee, tea, or soda. But don't quit caffeine suddenly, because that can also give you headaches.
Reduce eyestrain from computers by blinking frequently and looking away from the computer screen every so often. Make sure you have proper eyewear and that your monitor is set up properly, about an arm's length away.

Call 911 anytime you think you may need emergency care. For example, call if:

You have signs of a stroke. These may include:
○ Sudden numbness, paralysis, or weakness in your face, arm, or leg, especially on only one side of your body.
○ Sudden vision changes.
○ Sudden trouble speaking.
○ Sudden confusion or trouble understanding simple statements.
○ Sudden problems with walking or balance.
○ A sudden, severe headache that is different from past headaches.

Call your doctor now or seek immediate medical care if:
You have a fever and a stiff neck.
You have new nausea and vomiting, or you cannot keep down food or fluids.
Your headache gets much worse.

Watch closely for changes in your health, and be sure to contact your doctor if:

Your headaches get worse, happen more often, or change in some way.
You have new symptoms.
Your life is disrupted by your headaches. For example, you often miss work, school, or other activities.
You do not get better as expected.

contained.summary: Acute sinusitis, unspecified

payload.contentString:
Acute sinusitis is an inflammation of the mucous membranes inside the nose and sinuses. Sinuses are the hollow spaces in your skull around the eyes and nose. Acute sinusitis often follows a cold. Acute sinusitis causes thick, discolored mucus that drains from the nose or down the back of the throat. It also can cause pain and pressure in your head and face along with a stuffy or blocked nose. In most cases, sinusitis gets better on its own in 1 to 2 weeks. But some mild symptoms may last for several weeks. Sometimes antibiotics are needed if there is a bacterial infection.
Follow-up care is a key part of your treatment and safety. Please follow up with 2-5 days with your PCP

How can you care for yourself at home?

Use saline (saltwater) nasal washes. This can help keep your nasal passages open and wash out mucus and allergens.
○ You can buy saline nose washes at a grocery store or drugstore. Follow the instructions on the package.
○ You can make your own at home. Add 1 teaspoon of non-iodized salt and 1 teaspoon of baking soda to 2 cups of distilled or boiled and cooled water. Fill a squeeze bottle or a nasal cleansing pot (such as a neti pot) with the nasal wash. Then put the tip into your nostril, and lean over the sink. With your mouth open, gently squirt the liquid into the upper nostril. Repeat on the other side.

Try a decongestant nasal spray like oxymetazoline (Afrin). Do not use it for more than 3 days in a row. Using it for more than 3 days can make your congestion worse.

If needed, take an over-the-counter pain medicine, such as acetaminophen (Tylenol), ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin), or naproxen (Aleve). Read and follow all instructions on the label.

If the doctor prescribed antibiotics, take them as directed. Do not stop taking them just because you feel better. You need to take the full course of antibiotics.

Be careful when taking over-the-counter cold or flu medicines and Tylenol at the same time. Many of these medicines have acetaminophen, which is Tylenol. Read the labels to make sure that you are not taking more than the recommended dose. Too much acetaminophen (Tylenol) can be harmful.

Try a steroid nasal spray. It may help with your symptoms.

Breathe warm, moist air. You can use a steamy shower, a hot bath, or a sink filled with hot water. Avoid cold, dry air. Using a humidifier in your home may help. Follow the directions for cleaning the machine.

Call your doctor now or seek immediate medical care if:

You have new or worse swelling, redness, or pain in your face or around one or both of your eyes.
You have double vision or a change in your vision.
You have a high fever.
You have a severe headache and a stiff neck.
You have mental changes, such as feeling confused or much less alert.

Watch closely for changes in your health, and be sure to contact your doctor if:

You are not getting better as expected.
